The stickiness framework has been my lifeline:

1. better storytelling - ex: Patagonia
2. better quality - ex: iPhone
3. better price - ex: Costco
4. better curation - ex: SSENSE
5. social mission - ex: Dr. Bronner‚Äôs
6. new invention - ex: Roomba
7. network effect - ex: IG
Best case, you have multiple of these components

Building a sticky product isn't just about what you do, it's also about who you do it for

I made a typo in my newsletter last week. And it was embarrassing AF

But that little typo will end up bringing my business $400,000+ of extra recurring revenue 

The story of the most profitable typo I‚Äôve ever experienced:
After weeks of hard work, the day finally arrived

We were finally launching a new productized agency called Dispatch, unlimited beautiful design services (decks, apps, websites etc) for cheap

Me and the team were overwhelmed with excitement

You know that feeling‚Ä¶
The launch plan?

Send an email to my 97,000 Substack subscribers

Easy peasy...

All I have to do is come up with an interesting topic for the post and hit send

So, I think to myself what‚Äôs the juiciest topic I‚Äôve never shared that might be mega interesting?

OMG, I got it...
I write about the time Twitter tried to buy my company Late Checkout for 8 figures and I rejected it

People are going to want the juicy details so they‚Äôll read to the end

And that‚Äôs when I‚Äôll slap them with the hey, you should check out Dispatch

*and the crowd goes wild*
I hit send on the newsletter and wait anxiously for the feedback to start rolling in

But as I read through the email again, my heart sank

There it was, plain as day - a typo in the link

It was hideous...
Instead of https://t.co/VJ8rvoEDsB it was https://t.co/rgCGbDQl7z 

Im such an idiot

But I thought to myself:

"Maybe I'm overthinking it. No one will notice"

But I couldn't have been more wrong...
Because that's when the emails from subscribers started pouring in...

From well-known founders in Silicon Valley to a 15 year old high school student from Saint Louis, MO, they all noticed 

Arghhhh

My inbox was BLOWING up https://t.co/3NyTqA7IUm
And then the jokes start pouring in from my team. lmao

I deserved it

My fav?

"I'll bet https://t.co/S4fAx7MNte is available" 

Nope, probably taken... "by you greg..."

lolol https://t.co/353p5wjjW4
I was embarrassed and plain anxious 

But I was reminded of that old Seneca quote from Into the Quietude

"It is in the quietude of retreat that we are able to find ourselves again."

I closed my laptop, went for a walk and channel my inner Seneca

I needed "quietude" to function
I come back to my laptop to notice we have $1.25M of qualified leads!!

The sales team is already setting up calls

If 1/3 convert, that's literally $400k+

I don't get it... what happened? 

Did Elon Musk just tweet about me for being the world's dumbest CEO?
No!

The same people who were reaching out saying the link was wrong were inquiring about the design service

In fact, some of them were even making jokes about it and sharing the newsletter with their friends

I couldn't believe it...this campaign was a success
Lessons from the most profitable typo I've ever experienced:

- Don't be afraid to make mistakes - sometimes they can lead to unexpected opportunities
- Use AI to double check for human errors in your workflow
- If you're tired, hungry, mad, it's difficult to make clear decisions

A community can be a gold mine or a ghost town 

What kills a community

- No mission
- No memes
- No milestones
- No easy ways to contribute & get fast feedback
- Lack of rituals
- Lack of sense of belonging
- Lack of vibes
- Negativity

üßµ How to build a community that shines:
I'll explain by an example:

In 2018, the r/WeddingPlanning subreddit was struggling to gain traction. Despite having over 50,000 members, it was a ghost town

Members weren't engaging with each other, and the community was fizzling out

A community needs connection to thrive
The mods investigated and learned the subreddit was suffering from a lack of direction

Members didn't have a clear idea of what the subreddit was about, or what they could gain from being a part of it

Point: without direction, we lose our way
To fix this, the subreddit moderators crafted a clear mission statement that outlined the subreddit's purpose, values, and goals

They shared the mission statement with members and asked for feedback
The mission statement resonated with members, and they started to get excited about the subreddit's potential

All of a sudden, they began to feel a sense of belonging, and engagement starting ticking up

Point: A clear purpose inspires active participation
But the subreddit still needed something else to keep members engaged. The moderators realized that members needed something fun and easy to engage with. 

That's when they introduced a weekly thread for members to share their wedding planning memes

Memes rule!
Here's what happened:

Members were creating and sharing memes about their wedding planning experiences, and engagement skyrocketed

Members began to compete with each other to create the funniest or most relatable memes, and the subreddit's vibe became more playful & welcoming
Next up, the mods introduced milestone posts, where members could share their progress in their wedding planning journey.

Members began to celebrate each other's successes and offer advice and support. The subreddit became a true community, where members felt seen and heard
With a clear mission, a playful vibe, and easy ways to engage and share, the r/WeddingPlanning subreddit went from a ghost town to a gold mine

It now has over 400,000 members and continues to thrive as a go-to resource for couples planning their wedding
This is a mega-valuable community

There are hundreds of businesses to be built around this subreddit and the mods get to be at the center of it

Pretty cool...
To recap:

A thriving community is built on purpose, engagement, belonging, and positivity.

Keep these pillars strong, and your community will shine like gold üëë

The 90-9-1 rule says that 90% of your community will be passive, 9% active, 1% power

Despite having over 50,000 members, it was a ghost town

Members weren't engaging with each other, and the community was fizzling out

A community needs connection to thrive
The mods investigated and learned the subreddit was suffering from a lack of direction

Members didn't have a clear idea of what the subreddit was about, or what they could gain from being a part of it

Point: without direction, we lose our way

Observation: social media content is beginning to all look the same

Popular Twitter threads & TikToks all have the same format

It reminds me of how every city is beginning to look the same

Glass skyscrapers replacing local landmarks are killing  culture

It's a slippery slope
I believe that we've reached peak uniformness

The brands and creators that embrace diversity of content will outperform
I will write a blog post about this subject in more detail

I'm obsessed with cities, communities and content so this is a topic I care deeply about

I'll post it next week

You'll want to subscribe so you don't miss it:

https://t.co/F3G2HRaMg9

It's way easier to imitate than be original

And social platforms are optimized are dopamine rushes so why risk being original when you can employ tried, tested and true?

Same with cities. Easier to build cookie-cutter apartments than breaking the mold
Another reason:

Online courses that teach people the format to go viral

And once you go viral once, I'm convinced its the most addicting drug on the planet

You keep wanting to play the slot machine

Plenty of exceptional reasons to want to go viral

It changed my life and can change yours too
But I think it's important that we keep the internet weird

Celebrate diversity because it's an immense strength, not weakness

I want to challenge brands and creators to be yourself

How to think about audience vs community:
What is a community?

I use the TRIBE Test developed by @latecheckoutplz, the leading community product design agency/studio

1. Togetherness
2. Rituals
3. Identity
4. Belonging
5. Engagement

If you have 1-5, you've got a community https://t.co/HhKeqagbcc
Put another way:

A community is your local coffeeshop, you see familiar faces, you can be yourself and feel like you're at home
And community isn‚Äôt built in the comments of an Instagram post or TikTok video

It needs dedicated spaces to breathe and evolve

That could be IRL or digital spaces
What is an audience?

An audience is a TV station. You sit in front of the TV wanting to be entertained

It's one-way communication, it's broadcast

Once you have an audience, you can convert a portion to a community through rituals and habits like IRL events, Q&As, web3 etc
How do you know when you have a community that's working?

Keep an eye on retention (how often people come back) and engagement (how often people contribute)

You'll see it go up if there is community/market fit

There is real ROI in community
Once you have a strong community, you can build a community-based product 

That means:
- The community drives your growth
- The community helps define your product
- You spend less on ads

A community-based product is the new product-led growth

Frameworks I use everyday that have helped me sell companies, hire top talent, love life and build communities of millions of people

I can't live without them and maybe you can't either:
How to boost your productivity:
 
- Keep a productivity journal
- Time box your day (time for areas of focus)
- Set a timer (Google the ‚ÄúPomodoro technique‚Äù)
- Exercise everyday
- Take small breaks (Google ‚ÄúFika‚Äù)
- ‚ÄúGreat acts are made of small deeds‚Äù
- Find work you love to do
How to write copy that isn‚Äôt boring (and that sells):

- Don‚Äôt write copy, write stories
- Can be long or short, but must take you for a ride
- Focus entire story on the problem the customer has
- Share credibility
- Use inviting, warm words
- Create a clear call-to-action
How to avoid burnout:
 
- Avoid influencers who glamorize the grind
- Avoid screens when you can
- ~7h sleep
- Limit alcohol and caffeine
- Create boundaries from work. Unplug
- Take regular vacations
- Take regular ‚Äúme time‚Äù
- Go for regular walks
- Eat well
How to get your first 1000 community members:
 
- Decide on a community worth creating
- Establish a common goal of that community (learning X, doing Y)
- Build an audience first
- Convert audience into community (IG account into private Discord)
- Use community ambassadors
How to get your first 1000 customers:
 
- Do community ‚Äúdrops‚Äù, small microsites that spread the word
- Build an audience of 10000 people
- FOMO is your friend (exclusivity sells)
- Partner with communities to promote
- Go to your customers offline. Offline matters more than ever
How to come up with compelling startup ideas:
 
- Framework #1: X for Y (Robinhood for Canada)
- Framework #2: Anti-incumbent (Anti-Spotify, Anti-Amazon)
- Framework #3: Unbundling of X (Reddit, Facebook etc)
- Framework #4: Ask your community, they‚Äôll tell you
How to sell a company:
 
- Spend some of your energy building allies at incumbents
- Get them excited about what you‚Äôre doing
- Make them feel invested and jealous

essays.content:
The story of how I almost went broke selling my company to a $47 billion dollar company 

Lessons on startups, competition and life:
It's June 2016, I was having tea in SF and realized ‚Äúgroup chat is the new social network‚Äù

My thinking: everything would be verticalized

You‚Äôd have group chats around finance, around gaming, around work etc.

People want fluid, spontaneous communities/groups, not newsfeeds
I had previously sold a company. I created a short slide pitch deck

I raised $2m from some of the world‚Äôs best investors on an idea. From first pitch to money in the bank in 45 days

We had no product. No prototype. No users. Just a crazy idea
SF is sometimes magical like that. It was a privilege

We were off to the races
We built the product. We decided to focus on colleges

The idea: open up Islands on your campus, see group chats around you, form communities and create relationships

It was like Slack for communities. Focused on college

Discord was still focused on gamers at this time
We beta launched at 1 school: University of Western Ontario (Canadian school)

Why?

- If you screw up in Canada, no one pays attention
- If you screw up at NYU, everyone pays attention

Tip: places like New Zealand, Canada, Australia are great places to launch your app
We started scaling colleges

Hundreds of thousands of messages were flowing through the Islands systems

But retention sucked. Most people weren‚Äôt sticking around

Note: if people aren‚Äôt sticking around, you‚Äôre dead in the water
Mashable said we were taking over college campuses!

Axios said we were the next Facebook!

Marc Andreessen told me he loved our progress. He was a role model of mine. Validation! 

Realistically: we had blown through $1.5m and we were scrambling to get to product/market fit https://t.co/g291Ez6iLc
Most of the colleges we were live at were in the South of the US

Alabama. Mississippi. Georgia.

I had to get out of SF. The only way to zig-zag to product/market fit is to understand your community

I was 28. I went ‚Äúback to college‚Äù and spent 9 months of my life in Alabama https://t.co/x2au71mi9k
I think it was Inc Magazine that called me ‚Äúwhen 21 Jump Street meets Silicon Valley‚Äù

Damn. I had to do it. Sometimes you have to do crazy things to make your startup succeed.

Cost of doing startup business

Goodbye California.
We iterated on the product. Adding features. Removing features. Adding. Removing.

We obsessed over onboarding, viral loops, copy. That stuff matters

These details make or break products
FINALLY! We did it

We got retention in a place that it was higher than products like Twitter

Community-based product design works. I‚Äôll die on that cross

Islands started to work! Now it‚Äôs time to go raise VC to scale this baby
Picture this.

It‚Äôs 2018. Stock market is crashing. Its a social media winter

No one wanted to fund social apps. People are into AI, IoT and VR 

The narrative was: Facebook was just going to copy you. Just give up

Ouch.
Buuuut we had a product that was WORKING

Our metrics were 2x what some top Series A firms told me they needed to see in order to lead the round in 2016

Retention was high. Growth was good. The average user invited 2+ people

I had to raise this Series A...
Despite the social winter. VCs listened to me 

I pitched EVERYONE. Partners meetings at almost every major fund. I pitched about 100 VCs
Yet, no checks came in. I couldn‚Äôt get the money I needed 
I wanted to ‚Äúgo big or go home‚Äù

That‚Äôs why you start a social app. That‚Äôs why you move to Silicon Valley

It was time to go home...
So, we decided we should sell the company

In Dec 2018, we found a massive social media company that wanted to buy us

We met their leadership team. They loved us and were excited about the partnership

Not going to disclose who the buyer was but you know who you are ;)
WE DID IT!

We‚Äôre going to make internet history! Woo hoo! 

Champagne glasses cheersing üçæü•Ç

I‚Äôm picturing the news headlines now‚Ä¶

Can you blame me?

Until I get this call that would change my life a few weeks later...
I get a call on Christmas eve. It was one of their execs

The deal is off. They decided they‚Äôd just build their community feature internally

DAMN! We were banking on this 

Our bank account was almost zero.
I had to regroup. Greg this is going to work out. We‚Äôll find someone else

I had to personally fund the business until we figure this out

Merry Christmas to me üòÖ
Head up, I find my way in the door of any company (tech or not) interested in community

We started to get offers

Meanwhile, my bank account continued to dwindle...
A few months later. We finally sell the company

It‚Äôs WeWork. We‚Äôre excited about the partnership. I‚Äôm excited about the new chapter

Here's my final investor update. Please read https://t.co/oDBmGPWGjZ
I learned a lot from this rollercoaster

My biggest takeaways from this journey:
1. If you‚Äôre a VC-backed business, and you‚Äôre space isn‚Äôt hot anymore, funding becomes 100x harder

Trends come and go. So be sure to do everything in your power to NOT be dependent on venture capital

Avoid dependency
2.  The M&A process sucks

It‚Äôs a difficult process. Takes a toll on you

Key: optimize for multiple offers, not for price
3. Startups rewire your brain

I‚Äôll never be the same after this experience

Startups are as much as a business endeavor as a personal endeavor

It was an incredible experience
4. The secret to win the game against billion dollar competition: invent and play another game

The product features that made us stand out versus competition were the unique features

A good exercise: what‚Äôs the roadmap for the anti-Spotify, the anti-Instagram, the anti-Amazon
5. Mental health is wealth

I had so much support from good friends, family and had my own rituals like going to the Russian bath house to take steams/saunas to clear my mind

Do whatever you can to make sure you‚Äôre mentally well during these times
6. Be thankful for your team

My team kept a smile on my face during the good and the bad

Thank you to every member of the Islands team and special shoutout to my CTO @edeng. He gave me a roof above my head when things were rough

Well, it was an attic, but thats another story
The end.

- Make it fun

Great question!

- Community manager: makes sure the ship is smooth sailing, the captain 

- Community designer: is the ship's architect 

Note: often, the community manager IS the community designer

- A Product Manager strives for product/market fit
- A Community Designer strives for community/market fit

Success means retention and word-of-mouth skyrocket

People walk into the space and it makes them feel like alive
